title: To Track Virus, Governments Weigh Surveillance Tools That Push Privacy Limits
summary: Geolocation and facial-recognition systems can locate vectors of infections, but they also gather highly personal data. As the country scrambles to control the rapidly spreading coronavirus, government agencies are putting in place or considering a range of tracking and surveillance technologies that test the limits of personal privacy.

title: U.S. Blacklists New Islamic State Leader
summary: The U.S. also blacklisted the minister of defense in Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's government. The U.S. blacklisted the new leader of Islamic State as a specially designated global terrorist, the State Department said Tuesday.

title: What the Fed's Credit Facility Means for CFOs Facing a Cash Crunch
summary: The central bank took action to help big companies, but questions remain about the health of main street businesses that many supply chains rely on. The Federal Reserve's move to provide short-term funding to U.S. companies will likely allay the fears of many finance chiefs who are worried about preserving cash amid the coronavirus outbreak, economists said.

title: Coronavirus Fallout Reaches Some of the World's Remotest Mines
summary: Outside of the stock market rout, the pandemic hasn't had much effect on the biggest mining companies-until now. Four of the world's largest miners said they are closing production or slowing project construction, as fallout from the coronavirus pandemic reaches beyond the sector's share prices to some of its most-isolated mines.

title: New York City Residents May Have to Shelter in Place, de Blasio Says
summary: Mayor says decision could be made in next 48 hours, while Gov. Cuomo says he has no plans to quarantine New York City. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo and New York City's mayor delivered conflicting messages Tuesday on whether city residents could be forced to shelter in place because of the rapid spread of the new coronavirus.

title: U.S. Suspends Visa Processing in Mexico, Threatening Businesses Reliant on Seasonal Workers
summary: Disruption comes as farmers typically would be looking for foreign workers ahead of planting seasons. The State Department said it would stop processing most visas for U.S. entry in its offices across Mexico, including visas for seasonal workers, visitors and people looking to immigrate, in response to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Dispute Over Justice Department's Use of Overseas-Evidence Requests Grows
summary: A former prosecutor goes public with his allegation that such requests are abused. WASHINGTON-A dispute over whether the Justice Department has misused some foreign-evidence requests escalated this week, as prosecutors put forth an aggressive interpretation of their authority and a former prosecutor went public with additional allegations of unethical conduct.

title: Hotels Seek $150 Billion in Aid as Travel Plummets
summary: Mounting economic damage from coronavirus has created busy days for Washington lobbyists and trade groups; small players fear getting frozen out. The U.S. hotel industry asked the Trump administration for a $150 billion bailout Tuesday, joining the growing ranks of businesses appealing to the federal government to stave off insolvency after getting hammered by the fallout of the coronavirus.

title: The Fiscal Stimulus Panic
summary: $1,000 checks won't help the economy, but a new Fed backstop will.. We will survive the coronavirus panic as Americans adapt, as they always do. We're less confident of the Washington panic, as our politicians rush to throw money around without much thought or economic logic as they almost always do. At least the Federal Reserve stepped in Tuesday to address an immediate economic problem.

title: Britain's Better Stimulus
summary: Britain's new Chancellor fires a supply-side response to Covid-19.. The economic war Prime Minister Boris Johnson wanted to fight was for Britain's prosperity after Brexit. The war he has instead is against the damage wrought by Covid-19. His Chancellor of the Exchequer, Rishi Sunak, fired the first broadside Tuesday with a major raft of supply-side measures.

title: A Tax-Delay Boost
summary: Hard to believe, but the IRS delivers good news on filing returns.. Lawmakers are wrangling over how best to help Americans hit by the virus shutdown, but credit to the Trump Administration for moving decisively on one helpful idea. Its decision to delay IRS filing and payment deadlines to July 15 will be a boon to struggling Americans and an economy in need of liquidity.

title: Investors Hunt for Corporate-Bond Winners in Coronavirus Economy
summary: Investors are shying away from debt backing tourism and travel companies; health care holds up. Investors are racing to find winners and losers in the corporate-bond market as the coronavirus wreaks havoc on the markets.

title: Moderate Joe Moves Left
summary: He's courting Warren on bankruptcy, Bernie on free college and the NEA.. Joe Biden had his best debate on Sunday night, his first time mano a mano against Bernie Sanders, who stood a healthy six feet to Mr. Biden's left. Mr. Sanders argued the U.S. is unprepared for the coronavirus pandemic, since it has "thousands of private insurance plans" instead of a centralized health-care system.

title: Challenge for Policy Makers: Rescue Economy Without Fueling a Backlash
summary: Share buybacks raise eyebrows as government ponders rescues of airlines, other industries. As Washington rushes to aid airlines and other sectors crushed by the pandemic crisis, politicians face the challenge of saving the economy without unleashing the backlash that accompanied the last such rescue operation in 2008.

title: Report From New York's Containment Zone
summary: Mixed reviews in Westchester County for the government's handling of the Covid-19 outbreak.. When my wife and I quit Brooklyn 15 years ago to start a family in the suburbs, we were seeking a kind of refuge. The 9/11 attacks were still a recent memory. We wanted more living space and foliage, along with more safety. Apparently, so did a lot of other people. Our destination was sprawling Westchester County, just north of the Bronx, and it was full of New York City transplants. We bought our first house from one.

title: Questioning the Clampdown
summary: Will people lose faith when they find out they are expected to get the virus anyway?. Experts now agree the virus's spread can be slowed but not contained. It will take its place among mostly seasonal respiratory infections. After a time, recurrent outbreaks will be moderated by a large number of potential carriers who have immunity from their last infection.

title: America Wasn't Prepared for This Crisis
summary: Can the 'arsenal of democracy' ramp up production of masks and testing kits?. While the Covid-19 pandemic has focused attention on presidential leadership, it has also offered a pitiless X-ray of America's public-health and emergency-preparedness systems. Put simply: We weren't as ready as we should have been, and the price will be steep. As we pull out all the stops to meet the exigencies of the moment, we should be thinking hard about lessons for the future.

title: School's Out for the Coronavirus
summary: Students discuss what's lost and what could be gained as Covid-19 forces classes to move online.. Editor's note: This Future View is about how the fallout from Covid-19 could change the way we think about education. Next week we'll ask, "Have you noticed a generational difference in accepting the need for social distancing to ward off the new coronavirus?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before March 24. The best responses will be published that night.

title: How to Treat the Financial Symptoms of Covid-19
summary: Federal spending is needed but not enough. Making loans is better than writing checks. Avoid coercion.. The coronavirus pandemic is in danger of sparking a financial crisis. Stock-market plunges and volatility are reminiscent of September 2008. Strains are showing in credit and money markets.

title: Twitter Suppresses Speech by Calling It 'Manipulated Media'
summary: Imagine going after LBJ's 'Daisy Girl' ad lest viewers think the girl actually died in a nuclear strike.. Did Joe Biden endorse President Trump at a recent campaign event? "We can only re-elect Donald Trump," he said. But everyone understood that Mr. Biden either mixed up his words or was making an entirely different point.

title: 'The Return of the Russian Leviathan' Review: A Lust for Suffering
summary: Putin's domestic policies, says a Russian critic, are motivated by revenge, self-pity and a search for those who betrayed the wonderful U.S.S.R.. The original Russian title of this dazzling collection of essays by Sergei Medvedev, a social-science professor in Moscow and one of Russia's leading political commentators, was "The Crimean Period Park" (Park krymskogo perioda). The echo of "Jurassic Park" was surely intended. Mr. Medvedev sees Russia's annexation of Crimea and its war on Ukraine-both of which followed the ouster of Ukraine's Russia-backed leader in 2014-as marking a new geologic era in Russian politics and foreign policy. This book is an invitation to explore the park.

title: U.S. Delays April 15 Tax Payments for 90 Days for Most Americans
summary: Coronavirus disruption prompts tax agency to extend deadline, waive interest and penalties. WASHINGTON-The U.S. government will postpone the April 15 tax-payment deadline for millions of individuals, giving Americans an additional 90 days to pay their 2019 income-tax bills in an unprecedented move intended to ease the economic pain inflicted by the coronavirus.

title: Amid Coronavirus, It's a St. Patrick's Day Without Parades, Crowds or Green Beer
summary: Irish celebrations, family traditions are canceled. Molly Gstalter is missing out on a lot of must-dos this St. Patrick's Day, as the coronavirus pandemic nearly shut down the celebration of all-things Irish.

title: Coronavirus Sends Travel Business and Millions It Employs Into Crisis
summary: The pandemic is shaping up to be the biggest test the modern travel industry has ever faced. The coronavirus pandemic is devastating global travel, causing business to evaporate and forcing companies to slash payroll in what's shaping up to be the biggest test the modern travel industry has ever faced.

title: Ohio's Primary Postponement Sows Confusion Among Voters
summary: Governor puts off in-person voting, citing public-health crisis after court rules against delay. Ohio closed its polling places Tuesday, leaving primary voters confused and frustrated after the governor postponed in-person voting, citing the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Military Readies Hospital Ships for Deployment, to Open Its Labs
summary: Defense secretary says labs would help test civilians for coronavirus; Pentagon also plans to distribute equipment. The U.S. military said Tuesday it would open its labs, distribute key medical equipment and ready its hospital ships in response to the growing crisis surrounding coronavirus.

title: HSBC Appoints Noel Quinn as Permanent CEO
summary: Veteran preserves unbroken tradition of HSBC insiders leading the bank since it was founded in 1865. HSBC Holdings PLC has appointed Noel Quinn-a stalwart of the British bank-as chief executive seven months after he assumed the position on an interim basis.

title: Kevin Durant Among Four Brooklyn Nets Positive for Coronavirus
summary: The Nets' star, who said he is asymptomatic, is one of seven NBA players known to be infected with the virus. Kevin Durant and three other players for the NBA's Brooklyn Nets have tested positive for coronavirus, according to the team and media reports, as the disease continued to spread around the league with the largest known outbreak in American sports.

title: New FDA Test Policy Could Boost Availability, But Reduce Reliability
summary: Move should help east shortage of tests but may lead to inaccurate results. WASHINGTON-A federal agency's decision to allow lab companies to release coronavirus tests without prior government approval should help ease the shortage of test kits, but at the potential cost of compromised results, medical experts said Tuesday.

title: State Unemployment Sites See Surge in Jobless Claims
summary: Claims websites for New York, Oregon, Kentucky experience issues with traffic surge. Several state unemployment-benefits sites are malfunctioning amid a rise in claims from Americans who are out of work because of the novel coronavirus.

title: Fox Corp. to Buy Streaming Service Tubi
summary: Company strikes deal to acquire streaming service for as much as $490 million. Fox Corp. has struck a deal to acquire the streaming service Tubi in a deal worth as much as $490 million, the company said Tuesday.

title: Disney Looks to Sell TrueX, Ad-Tech Firm It Absorbed From Fox
summary: TrueX is best known for offering interactive ads. Walt Disney Co. is looking to sell TrueX, an advertising-technology company it absorbed as part of its $71.3 billion acquisition of 21st Century Fox assets last year, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Iraq Taps New Candidate as Prime Minister, Testing Relations With Iran
summary: Pro-Iranian factions denounced the designation of Adnan al-Zurfi as Iraq's new prime minister. Iraq's president designated a former provincial governor with American citizenship as prime minister, drawing criticism from Iran's allies in the country amid new tensions between Washington and Tehran.

title: Marriott Starting to Furlough Tens of Thousands of Employees
summary: Coronavirus outbreak has led to widespread travel cancellations and government-ordered travel restrictions. Marriott International Inc., the world's largest hotel company with nearly 1.4 million rooms world-wide, said it is starting to furlough what it expects will be tens of thousands of employees as it ramps up hotel closings across the globe.

title: Coronavirus Upends Senior-Housing Business, Sending Shares Reeling
summary: Any additional contagion in care facilities could dissuade new residents from moving in, investors fear. The coronavirus has been sending shares of elder-care facilities into a tailspin over concern that any additional contagion in senior-care buildings could hurt operations and lead to occupancy declines.

title: Fintechs Get Clearer Rules on Banking Licenses Under FDIC Plan
summary: Proposal would impose new oversight on owners of industrial loan companies. WASHINGTON-Financial-technology firms and other businesses seeking to offer banking services will have a clearer set of rules to follow under a proposal by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.

title: Private Jets Get a Lift as Commercial Planes Are Grounded
summary: As coronavirus forces airlines to cut back, some companies and wealthy families turn to charters. Some business executives and wealthy travelers are turning to private jets as the fast-spreading coronavirus prompts commercial airlines to slash service.

title: Traders Bet on Falling 'Fear Gauge'
summary: Some investors are wagering on a rapid fall in the VIX after it closed at its highest level ever Monday. The Cboe Volatility Index, or VIX, closed at its highest level in history Monday when U.S. shares recorded the steepest decline since the Black Monday stock-market crash of 1987. Some investors are already betting on its rapid fall.

title: Scientists Crunch Data to Predict How Many People Will Get Coronavirus
summary: Outbreak analytics fills void when number of confirmed Covid-19 cases doesn't tell the whole story. Epidemiologists are teaming up with data scientists to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus by tapping big data, machine learning and other digital tools.

title: New York Restaurants Hope 'Bond Offering' Will Save Businesses
summary: Plan is to provide another revenue stream when restaurants have been forced by the state to limit business. As concern among New York City restaurants grows about the financial toll the novel coronavirus is taking, some are trying to offset their losses with a new initiative: selling "dining bonds."

title: FedEx Pulls Guidance, Will Reduce Capacity as Coronavirus Slows Economy
summary: Delivery giant withdrew its earnings forecast for the first time in its 50-year history. FedEx Corp. pulled its financial forecasts and said it would continue to reduce its delivery capacity, as the coronavirus pandemic disrupts global trade patterns and economic activity.

title: Cautious Voters Venture Out to Cast Ballots
summary: Some left their houses for first time in days amid coronavirus pandemic to visit unevenly staffed polling places. For many voters going to the polls Tuesday in three states, the trip was their first time out of their homes since they started practicing social distancing to deal with the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Financial Institutions Share Stockpiles of Face Masks With NYC Hospitals
summary: Goldman Sachs, Nasdaq, Mastercard respond with supplies as medical association extends plea. The Greater New York Hospital Association is asking New York City's large companies and financial institutions to share their stockpiles of face masks as local hospitals grapple with dwindling supplies.

title: Utilities Shares Outperform as Stocks Stage Rebound
summary: Utilities stocks recorded their largest one-day percentage gain since 2008. That was quick: Utilities stocks recorded their largest one-day percentage gain since 2008, rebounding from painful losses Monday, when the segment recorded its biggest fall ever.

title: Stocks Rise Sharply in Volatile Trading
summary: Dow industrials, S&P 500 close more than 5% higher in turbulent session following punishing selloff. U.S. stocks clawed back some of the ground they lost during Monday's punishing selloff as the Federal Reserve and White House moved to soften the economic blow of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: 'Francis Bacon: Late Paintings' Review: A Conjurer of Strange and Terrible Beauty
summary: Bacon's troubled life is reflected in his art, which continued to develop even in the twilight of his career.. Houston

title: Fed Repos See Robust Demand, Lifting Central Bank Loans to Markets
summary: Primary dealers sought $142.65 billion in overnight operation, while 14-day repo saw dealers get $45 billion. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York intervened in financial markets Tuesday with three operations to extend short-term loans it has made available to large banks, while also expanding the amount of money it is willing to loan those banks.

title: Oil-Field-Service Stocks Are Getting Scrapped
summary: Prospects for oil-patch contractors and equipment suppliers look dim amid a steep decline in drilling activity. Shares of companies that help energy producers get oil and gas out of the ground have become collateral damage in the global oil-price war.

title: Companies Mull Suspending, Ramping Up Share Buyback Plans Amid Coronavirus
summary: Gap, DSV Panalpina and major banks said they would halt their repurchase programs. Finance chiefs are grappling with whether to make share repurchases or hold on to cash as stock prices fall on fears surrounding the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Some Top Asset Managers Think Financial Markets Should Close
summary: On a call with Bank of England governor, asset managers were split on whether to close markets. Executives from some of the biggest asset managers told the Bank of England's new governor on Monday that financial markets should close for two weeks as the world confronts the coronavirus pandemic, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Explaining the Fed's Intervention in Commercial-Paper Markets
summary: The central bank dusted off a tool from the financial crisis in a bid to calm vital funding markets. The Federal Reserve dusted off a tool from the financial crisis in a bid to calm vital funding markets that have broken down in recent weeks-establishing a lending facility to support the $1.2 trillion market for short-term commercial paper. Here is what that means and why it matters:

title: New York City's Blitz to Create Online Classes for 1.1 Million Students
summary: Training for roughly 80,000 teachers began in preparation for internet-based lessons that are meant to start on March 23. New York City's public-school system of more than 1.1 million students is undergoing a big shift to remote learning this week, after schools were closed to help contain the spread of the coronavirus.

title: Tupperware Misses On Planned Obsolescence
summary: Tupperware sets the highest standard in quality.. The market for food containers may have evolved over 74 years, but Tupperware remains the superior product in the field for its durability, longevity and value when cost per use is calculated over the life of the container ("Tupperware Loses Its Grip on Consumers," Business News, March 9). Tupperware sets the highest standard in quality that no other container on the market can meet, and it is guaranteed for life.

title: Corona: U.S. vs. European's Health Systems
summary: Joseph Sternberg implies that Italy's apparent inability to deliver effective treatment for the severest Covid-19 cases is largely the result of its "long-term failures to invest in" its health-care system.. In "Europe's Coronavirus Fate is Already Sealed" (Political Economics, March 13), Joseph Sternberg implies that Italy's apparent inability to deliver effective treatment for the severest Covid-19 cases is largely the result of its "long-term failures to invest in" its health-care system. He notes that Italy had only 2.6 acute-care hospital beds per 1,000 residents as of 2016, and suggests that this is because Italy is "significantly more dependent on direct government financing of health-care" than some other European countries. He goes on to say that voters ought to consider "how much one trusts central health planners to make wise long-term decisions that boost resilience in the face of unusual dangers." The same issue has "U.S. Hospitals Face Major Challenges" (Page One) stating that the U.S. had just 2.8 hospital beds per 1,000 people in 2016. It seems to me that our own hospitals, public and private, have done no better at long-term planning. Voters should know that, too.

title: Fight the Virus by Washing the Office Dishes
summary: I don't understand the fury about dirty dishes at work. In this age of coronavirus, I think it would be a wonderful opportunity to wash my hands many times a day on company time.. Dereliction of duty in the corporate kitchen is a timeless phenomenon ("Sure, Leave Your Mug in the Office Sink. No One Minds," Page One, March 11). Forty years ago, as a neophyte manager, I confronted the same communal myth that there's a kitchen-dishes fairy who magically brought order to the chaos that everyone felt entitled to leave. Being a callow manager, I thought it would be precedent-setting for the manager to do the dishes, until I realized it was entirely unrequited and unappreciated.

title: Disasters Usually Bring Us Together; This One Isolates
summary: This coronavirus scare is different. It's isolating.. Regarding your editorial "America's Self-Shutdown" (March 13): When we were attacked on 9/11 the country came together and agreed that we would not let fear of the terrorists cause us to stay home and abandon our way of living. We would continue to fly on airplanes, and go to ballgames, malls, concerts and other gatherings that make America what it is.

title: The Best Home Workout Machine? It's Not a Treadmill.
summary: Exercising exclusively at home? For efficient, full-body workouts, rowing machines beat treadmills or bikes, but they have a bad rep. These chic, techy upgrades aim to change that. TREADMILLS AND indoor bikes have evolved from unsightly basement-dwellers on which suburbanites hung laundry to statement pieces for the living room. Now rowing machines, long shunned for their clanking chains and dusty flywheels, are undergoing their own Peloton-esque evolution. These chic devices also let anyone aspiring to fitness stream live and on-demand workouts via HD screens or race against at-home athletes across the world.

title: The Staying Inside Guide: Discovering Classical Architecture
summary: In the wake of the controversy over the design of federal buildings, our critic samples streaming videos that shed light on the language of pediments and columns and on the battle between traditionalists and the moderns.. Confinement makes us more aware of architecture, if only of that little sliver of space in which we find ourselves penned. But so long as we have the internet we can be, like Hamlet, "kings of infinite space," and contemplate all of architecture at our leisure. Perhaps this is a good time to reconsider the most important architectural story of recent days, the revelation last month that the government is considering a policy preferring "the classical architectural style" for federal buildings in Washington "absent special extenuating factors necessitating another style."

title: Telemedicine Gets a Boost From Coronavirus Pandemic
summary: Medicare patients get more flexibility in seeking remote treatment. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration expanded access to telemedicine in Medicare, a move that could relieve crowding at hospitals but strain companies facing a surge in demand from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: What the Government Can and Can't Do About the Economic Fallout From the Coronavirus
summary: Economic challenges include disruptions in supply chains and people who have lost jobs or income-and can't spend. Editor's note: This is an excerpt from our newsletter, "2020 Election+Business," a weekly dive into the intersection of business, finance and the 2020 election. You can sign up here.

title: Economic Downturn Catches State Unemployment Programs Unprepared
summary: Trust funds in 22 states and jurisdictions aren't recession-ready, data show. State unemployment insurance systems across the U.S. aren't ready for the likely surge in worker claims from the U.S. economic downturn triggered by the new coronavirus pandemic.

title: New Jersey Coronavirus Patient Is Missing After Giving False Name
summary: Officials urge woman to return to hospital where she tested positive. Officials are searching for a woman who gave a false name and address to doctors at a New Jersey hospital before testing positive for the coronavirus.

title: Blood-Sample Shortages Slow Drug Search
summary: Drugmakers aiming to develop antibody-based treatments are struggling to get the building blocks they need. To cure the sick, drug researchers first need the blood of the healthy.

title: Europe's Fiscal Antidote to Coronavirus Crisis Risks Deepening Economic Gaps
summary: The stimulus moves could help fiscally sound countries including Germany but destabilize countries with higher debt such as Italy. European governments have pledged hundreds of billions of euros to help economies, companies and workers hit by the coronavirus, applying tools developed during the euro crisis and casting aside strict prohibitions on state subsidies.

title: This Kitchen Tool Will Quietly, Reliably Improve Your Quality of Life
summary: If only everything could be as blessedly simple as this can opener. Streamlined but sturdy, it gets the job done with zero drama-something we all need right now. FOR THE PANTRY stocked up with plenty of provisions, a quality can opener is key. From Japan, the Gangy kankiri (that's Japanese for can opener) is a favorite among chefs and campers alike, with good reason. Painted a particularly cheerful shade of red, the streamlined stainless-steel tool has a ferocious carbon-steel blade that moves through metal with minimal elbow grease expended. Just clip the kankiri onto the edge of the can you wish to open, sink the thick-gauge blade into the top, and with a simple twist of the wrist continue moving the tool around the perimeter until the task is complete. This thing is mercifully unfussy, cleverly designed, free of flimsy moving parts, dishwasher safe and built to last. It opens bottles too. And you certainly can't argue with the price. $5, korin.com

title: Isolate So Government Will Let Us Have Our Economy Back
summary: You don't have to believe in the worst-case medical scenario to see the urgent need to fight infection.. The media and political class is largely uninterested in exploring the costs and benefits of various responses to the coronavirus. The consensus is to shut down much of the economy and create massive government programs to clumsily offset the damage. Individuals must now recognize the need to self-isolate. Whatever one thinks about risk, it's clear that Americans must slow the spread of infection enough to persuade politicians to stop reacting to it. While you save lives, you can also save jobs-and one of them might be your own.

title: Giving Americans Money to Offset Coronavirus Impact Gains Trump Administration Support
summary: Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says 'Americans need cash now;' lawmakers in both parties urge government to send funds to households to cushion economic pain. WASHINGTON-An idea that had little traction just a few days ago-sending direct checks to Americans-is gaining fast momentum as the Trump administration came on board Tuesday.

title: Dollar Surges as Investors Seek Shelter From Market Disruption
summary: Stress in market for dollar funding outside U.S. eases after Fed supports short-term commercial debt markets. The U.S. dollar surged against major currencies as stress in the market for dollar funding outside the U.S. worsened before the Federal Reserve stepped in on Tuesday to boost support for the short-term money market.

title: How to Mix Drinks Like a Parisian
summary: We reached pastry chef-turned-cocktail maven David Lebovitz in his Paris apartment, where he paused, mid-stir, to share a few tips on mixing drinks and other tasks worth mastering. IMAGINE A FRENCHMAN with a glass of something in hand, and chances are a glass of wine immediately comes to mind. Then stop and think about how many apéritifs are, in fact, French. Dubonnet, Pastis, Suze, Lillet, Noilly Prat-and those are just the best known-can be found in nearly every neighborhood café in France. What's more, in recent years cocktails have become all the rage in French restaurants and bars, particularly in Paris. "Drinking French" (Ten Speed Press), the new recipe book from David Lebovitz , explores French cocktails old and new while providing essential information on everything from the history of spirits to the mores of what to drink and when.

title: Costco Buys Logistics Firm From Sears Owner for $1 Billion
summary: Deal for Innovel Solutions, a last-mile delivery company, is Costco's largest since merger with Price Club in 1993. Costco Wholesale Corp. on Tuesday said it acquired logistics company Innovel Solutions from Transform Holdco LLC, the operator of Sears and Kmart stores, for $1 billion in cash.

title: Facebook Gives Employees Extra $1,000 and Good Reviews Amid Coronavirus
summary: The social-media giant also plans to provide $100 million in cash and advertising credits to small businesses. Facebook Inc. will give all of its full-time employees an additional $1,000 in their next paycheck and will give everyone the same "exceeds expectations" performance review for the first half of the year.

title: American Hospitals Can Avoid Italy's Fate
summary: Deploy telemedicine to determine who needs emergency care, waive licensing rules and more.. China locked down Hubei province in late January in a last-ditch attempt to slow the novel coronavirus epidemic. But hospital admissions for Covid-19 continued to rise for another four weeks. At the epidemic's peak, nearly 20,000 patients were hospitalized, more than 10,000 in severe or critical condition.

title: The Dog Days of a Pandemic Spring
summary: The season of new beginnings is off to a melancholy start.. Our old and ailing terrier has improbably lived to see another spring, though he approaches the warming season more timidly these days. He once bolted from the door on March mornings to attend to his duties, but now he confronts the new grass with caution, like an astronaut slowly planting his heel on the moon. Terriers are typically a zealous bunch, so it's been a somber thing to see our aged mutt begin to doubt his footing.

title: Bronx School Gets Early Look at Remote Learning
summary: Riverdale Country School offers a hint at what some students and teachers can expect. New York City schools are preparing to implement remote-learning plans in the wake of the decision to shut down the nation's largest school system.

title: Latest Hot Spot for Coronavirus Hoarders: The Public Library
summary: Hearing of imminent closures, people rush to pick up books and DVDs; 'this is what Black Friday must be like at Walmart'. MT. LEBANON, Pa.-More than a dozen people were waiting outside the public library here shortly before the 9 a.m. opening Saturday.

title: House Democrats Scale Back Paid-Leave Program in Coronavirus-Aid Bill
summary: Measure would still provide two weeks of sick leave to a wide swath of workers, but restrict eligibility for further time off. WASHINGTON-The Democratic-led House scaled back a paid-leave program that the chamber had tried to enact days earlier, following pressure from businesses worried about financial burdens from the sweeping bill in response to the coronavirus crisis.

title: Without Sports, Bettors Are Getting Creative
summary: As sporting events are largely canceled, sports books are offering wagers on the weather instead. Adjusting to social distancing is a major challenge for all of society. This is especially true for sports gamblers, who are seemingly left with nothing to bet on until the world begins to return to normal.

title: What Are the Risks of Food and Grocery Deliveries?
summary: As the new coronavirus keeps people away from restaurants and grocery stores, more people are turning to deliveries. What precautions should you take?. As people rely more on deliveries for groceries and food-especially now that so many restaurants are closing-a new concern is emerging amid the coronavirus outbreak: How safe is the food delivery?

title: The Slip Dress: Lingerie or Wardrobe Staple?
summary: It's back. As worn by Drew Barrymore and Kate Moss in the 1990s, the silky slip can be a louche, barely-there basic to be layered over tops and under blazers.

title: As Coronavirus Clampdown Widens, IOC Presses Ahead to Tokyo
summary: The International Olympic Committee said it is 'fully committed' to an Olympics in July as scheduled, despite training and qualifying disruptions. The International Olympic Committee again insisted Tuesday it wasn't changing course on the Tokyo Olympics scheduled for July, even as qualification events around the world are scratched and athletes in multiple countries are reshaping training schedules around lockdowns caused by the novel coronavirus.

title: Project Digs Deeper Into Teenage Smartphone Use
summary: Researchers want to examine how adolescents and others use their phones to nearly the second; 'The phone really is this mirror'. Smartphones have radically changed the way teens consume information. What hasn't kept pace, researchers say, is the way we study how they consume it.

title: Amazon Prioritizes Medical Supplies, Household Staples From Merchants
summary: E-commerce giant says independent merchants unable to ship products other than high-demand items to its warehouses until April 5. Amazon.com Inc. said it is taking steps to prioritize shipments of medical supplies, household staples and other high-demand products in the wake of surging demand due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Iranians Defy Authorities in Bid to Access Holy Sites Closed Amid Coronavirus
summary: President seeks to balance quarantine demands against opposition to limiting activity as some warn fatalities could reach millions.

title: Tom Brady Gives New England the 'Big Goodbye'
summary: On the eve of free agency, a stunning farewell from the most decorated quarterback in NFL history. Yowza. So much for "The End of Sports Talk."

title: U.S. February Retail Spending Drop Shows Coronavirus Concerns Started to Take Hold
summary: February factory production was broadly flat, another sign the economy began to strain. WASHINGTON-American shoppers reined in their spending last month and factory production was broadly flat, signs the economy began to strain as the threat from the new coronavirus started to take hold.

title: Biden Gets Secret Service Protection

summary: Antiviral drug remdesivir appeared to have an effect in American cruise passengers treated in Japan, although data are limited. title: Soccer's European Championship Postponed Until Summer of 2021
summary: The 24-team tournament was due to unfold in 12 cities across the continent this June and July. But to stave off the risk of dollar-funding markets seizing up, more help is needed for a broader range of countries. Emerging markets look particularly vulnerable.

title: Coronavirus Pushes China's Economy to the Brink
summary: Business activity, for the first time on record, turned broadly negative, as home and retail sales, construction activity and factory output all fell. SHANGHAI-Business activity in China turned broadly negative for the first time on record as home sales, construction activity, retail sales and factory output plunged, pushing unemployment to a record high, signs of the costly economic damage associated with trying to control the spread of the coronavirus.

title: Ohio Election in Chaos as Governor Says Polls to Close, Defying State Judge
summary: Top public health official will order polls closed Tuesday over coronavirus fears, after a judge blocked the state's last-minute attempt to postpone its primary election. title: Shedding 2008 Stigma, Biggest U.S. Banks Borrow Straight From the Fed
summary: Financial Services Forum says move should 'reassure financial institutions of all sizes' that they should use Fed's discount window. summary: Sanders had been expected to repeat his 2016 victory in state's Democratic contest. Joe Biden narrowly defeated Bernie Sanders in last week's Democratic presidential primary in Washington state, according to projections from the Associated Press.

summary: Defense sought a mistrial over coronavirus, citing risks of jury deliberating in close quarters. title: FDA to Allow Marketing of Coronavirus Test Kits Without Prior Approval
summary: U.S. regulator takes action to increase availability of tests to the public. title: Some Senators Question House Coronavirus Response Bill
summary: Lawmakers start discussing large stimulus package as Congress seeks to protect itself from virus. title: Coronavirus Already Taking Big Toll on Urban Malls
summary: Falling foot traffic, orders from authorities to close, could prompt retailers to seek relief from lenders and landlords. Malls in dense, urban locations have in recent years have generally been more profitable than those in sparsely-populated areas, because foot traffic is typically stronger. But with the coronavirus spreading at a faster rate in metropolitan areas, many of these malls are poised to take a big hit. Some tenants, likely to be hurt by falling foot traffic and by orders from the authorities to close, may struggle to pay their rent.
